You need to start making food substitutes and using other tricks to help you stay away from sugary carbohydrates without nutritive value.Stop all sugary drinks as they only make you hungry.  Change to water and unsweetened tea.  Or make your own tea and sweeten it with agave nectar as you can control how much you use and it doesn't raise your blood sugar like other sweeteners.  Yet it is natural.At snack time, have a piece of fruit and nothing else.  A banana is fine, or an apple or orange.  Try having a cup of hot tea when you want something. Don't worry about calories when you are having one piece of whole fruit.  It has fiber and nutrition and is filling and the object is to keep you from eating the addicting foods you crave.Fill up your plate with a mix of vegetables and a small piece of lean meat, poultry or fish.  You could have a small potato or small sweet potato now and then, but avoid anything fried, remove skin from poultry.  You may cook with a small amount of butter mixed with olive oil, but avoid batter coatings.  I hear coconut oil is very good for cooking.Once those evil foods are out of your system, which happens after the first week or two, it will get easier.I disagree with the other poster who suggested artificial sweeteners.  These are not healthy and the body still treats them like sugar as far as insulin release.Don't eat fast food.  Avoid desserts.  Avoid packaged foods.  Try to shop in the outside aisles of the grocery store.  Then you cook your own and have more control.  Weight watchers has recipes on line I believe.

I have diabetes. What I have done may seem extreme but I cut out all starch from my diet. No pasta no beans, corn, peas, or anything made with white or whole grain flour. No rice, oatmeal or other hot or cold cereals. No potatoes even sweet potatoe. What I do eat is non starch veggies, nuts, lean protein, yogurt milk etc. Plus any fruit I want even an occasionall banana.  My cholesterol is normal now, my A1C's stay under 6.0. Big bonus I am losing weight. Good luck
